title.narrative: URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of

description.narrative: URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of Mercury Containing Products And Their Wastes. Gestión Ambientalmente Adecuada del Ciclo de Vida de los Productos que contienen Mercurio y sus Desechos..

title.narrative: URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of

description.narrative: URU/13/G32 Environmental Sound Life-Cycle Management of Mercury Containing Products And Their Wastes. Gestión Ambientalmente Adecuada del Ciclo de Vida de los Productos que contienen Mercurio y sus Desechos..
Energy - policy, planning and administration

The objective of the project is protect human health and the environment from Mercury releases originating from the intentional use of mercury in products and the unsound management and disposal of such products
No. of Hg-containing medical devices and energy saving light sources decontaminated and disposed of within the project period (2014 – 2017).

comment.narrative: In Uruguay there are no adequate storage, decontamination and disposal solutions in place for Mercury containing product waste. Most of such wastes are disposed of along with regular household waste.

In total the project expects to recover 330 kg of Mercury as a direct outcome of the project’s implementation. In addition, changed practices will also result in sustained Mercury reductions of approximately 72.5 kg Hg/year.

The project has set-up a logistics, technology and business model expert team (LTBM) which works under the guidance of the project coordinator and in close collaboration with all projects stakeholders: Scientific and Technological Pando Park and Pole (PCTP), National Administration of Power Plants and Energy Transmission (UTE) and National Environment Directorate (DINAMA).
In April a first field visit took place in order to: quantify the main existing Hg-waste storage facilities (Pereira Rossell Hospital, ASSE, LATU); identify the capacity and treatment process performed by companies authorized by DINAMA to work with this waste (Triex and MÃ¡rgenes del Rio) and review existing initiatives for collection (MIEM, IMM tank lighting, CIU and UTE lamps collection campaign in order to remove 1,200,000 waste lamps.
A first draft of the mercury waste collection, transportation, treatment and disposal solution was produced at the end of June.

description.narrative: Quantity (kg) of elemental Hg safeguarded which has been recovered from the decontamination process.

comment.narrative: If not disposed of, such wastes are kept in inappropriate interim storage locations.
Elemental Hg recovered from treatment/decontamination has been safely stored (at the Chlor-Alkali facility), exported to a long-term storage facility or immobilized using appropriate technologies
Not applicable to this reporting period (This activity is expected to take place once the treatment facility is in operation.

description.narrative: Safe decontamination options for Mercury containing products established.

comment.narrative: n the whole of Uruguay there are no options for the sound decontamination, storage or disposal of Mercury containing products.
Treatment facility constructed (in-line with Basel Convention guidelines and in compliance with national regulations).

Technical specifications for the international bidding process of the treatment facility, which is expected to be launched in September 2015, are being developed by the international expert in close coordination with the project team.
An agreement was held with the Scientific and Technological Pando Park to determine the location of the treatment facility. The architectural project is being developed by technical experts from the Scientific and Technological Pando Park and Pole.

description.narrative: Safe interim storage (to serve decontamination facility) for Mercury containing products established.

comment.narrative: Interim storage facility establish/upgraded to serve the decontamination facility for storage of Hg-containing wastes prior to treatment (in-line with BC guidelines and in compliance with national regulations).
The interim storage facilities are being designed by the LTBM team as part of the mercury waste collection, transportation, treatment and disposal solution.

description.narrative: Environmental and bio-monitoring programme developed.

comment.narrative: Environmental and bio-monitoring programme in place to monitor Hg levels in air, soil, water as well as in biological samples (in the decontamination facility, interim storage, final storage of elemental Mercury as well as in the immediate surroundings)
The environmental and bio-monitoring programme is being designed by the LTBM team as part of the mercury waste collection, transportation, treatment and disposal solution

description.narrative: Strengthen the regulatory and policy framework to allow for life-cycle management of mercury containing products and their wastes. (Equivalent to activity in ATLAS)
National Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) policy and regulations for mercury containing products adopted and introduced.

comment.narrative: There are no financial mechanisms in place that promote the LCM of Hg containing lamps (CFLs and tubes).

EPR for Hg-containing lamps established as a tool to provide for the financial resources necessary to cover operational costs of the collection, interim storage, decontamination and disposal of Hg-containing lamps costs.

The LTBM team is currently developing the plan/approach for the waste mercury collection, transportation, treatment and disposal system, which includes technical requirements, a business plan and logistical requirements and using the EPR as a tool.
Terms of reference for the hiring of a legal expert to support the National Environment Directorate (DINAMA) in the drafting of the EPR policy and regulations are being developed for publication at end of July 2015.

description.narrative: Strengthened policy and regulatory framework to enable the phase-out/down of mercury containing products and encourage Hg-free or lower level Hg products.

comment.narrative: There are no restrictions on the importation of high Hg-content lamps (CFLs, tubes) or Hg-containing medical devices.

EU RoHS directives for lighting products transposed into national regulations through a degree (restricting importation of high Hg content lamps). MSP degree prescribing a phased approach/total phase-out for the use of Hg-containing devices at Health-care facility level developed.
An agreement was reached with MSP for the development of this regulation by the Ministry´s legal advisers during the second semester of 2015.
Guidelines on the management, storage and disposal of Hg containing lamps are not available.
Guidelines for the management, storage and disposal of mercury containing products developed for large public and private entities developed.

The guidelines for handling, storage and disposal of mercury containing products are being developed by the LTBM team as part of the mercury waste collection, transportation, treatment and disposal solution .
In 2011, a guideline was developed on the management of mercury waste for implementation at hospital level. However, in most facilities, Hg management practices have not improved.
National plan(s) on the LCM of mercury containing products (CFLs/tubes; medical devices; dental amalgam) developed

The solid waste specialist consultant is drafting the national plan on the LCM of products containing mercury and mercury wastes that is expected to be presented on September 2015 to the authorities for validation in November 2015.
Guidelines on the management of dental amalgam are not available.
Guidelines on the management of dental amalgam developed.
No progress on this reporting period.

description.narrative: Improved adherence to the sound collection, (temp.) storage and treatment of products containing mercury (in particular project partners and model facilities)

comment.narrative: Annexes of the BC have been transposed in the Hazardous Waste Law (law 17.220/1999), which refers in specific to hazardous waste streams including waste containing mercury and regulates storage, transportation and disposal of hazardous waste, including Hg containing products.

Guidelines and legal provisions with respect to the sound collection, (temp.) storage and treatment of products containing mercury (and the storage of elemental mercury), will be reviewed based on int. best practices (Basel Convention) and revised/developed if necessary.

The guidelines and the description of the regulatory framework with respect to collection, storage, treatment and disposal system are being developed by the LTBM team and are expected to be presented at a workshop to be held in December 2015.
No norm is available that regulates the decontamination of Hg containing products
Norm is available
No progress during this reporting period.

description.narrative: Development of environmentally sound schemes and business models for the collection, treatment and disposal of mercury wastes
Mercury releases from priority sectors reduced and segregated Hg containing waste streams augmented.

comment.narrative: Current “stockpiles” (underestimated) are described in the project’s baseline and on page 8 footnote 932.
Waste management committees operationalized in each model facility.

The Health Institutions’ Project partners – the Ministry of Public Health and ASSE - are in the process of selecting 13 model institutions.
A call for applicants for a Management Committee Consultant to work at the Model Health Facilities is on going. The Consultant will be responsible for: (i) joining the management committee if existing or promoting its formation; (ii) promoting the sessions of the Management Committee; (iii) developing guidelines for mercury waste management at healthcare facilities; (iv) looking for mechanisms to legitimize the management committee.

description.narrative: Number of private sector operators, model healthcare facilities and PCTP staff capacitated in best practices related to collection, storage, treatment of Hg containing products and long-term safe storage of elemental Mercury, as well as the use of cost-effective Hg-free or low-Mercury content alternatives (if applicable)

comment.narrative: Some model facilities have waste management committees in place (a few of the HCFs), but most do not.
Hg baseline assessments (procurement, use, management, disposal, storage, etc) completed for each model facility.
Not applicable until the consultant is hired and the model institutions have been selected, as these assessments are part of his/her responsibility.
None of the model facilities have Hg management or phase-out plans in place, waste is either improperly stored or disposed of.
Mercury management and phase-out plans developed and implemented at each model facilities.
Not applicable until the consultant is hired and the model institutions have been selected, as the phase out plans are part of his/her responsibility.
Cost-effective Hg-free alternatives for medical devices and low Hg content CFLs and tubes are available in the country.
Study on staff preferences on cost-effective Hg-free alternatives conducted at the model HCFs

The consultant for evaluation of Alternative Technologies has been selected.. Among the consultant´s responsibilities that (s)he carries out a participatory and consultative process with health institutions to propose and evaluate alternative mercury-free medical instruments.
500 personnel of model facilities trained in LCM of Hg containing wastes and waste products.
Not applicable until the consultant is hired and the model institutions have been selected, as the training of personnel is part of his/her responsibility.
Mercury-free alternatives introduced at the project'??s model HCFs through adaptation of procurement practices.
Not applicable until the consultant has been hired.
Collection systems for Hg containing products operational.
Not applicable until the consultant has been hired

description.narrative: Business models and cost recovery arrangements (CRA) for the collection, transport, temporary storage and treatment of different types of Hg wastes operational and financially sustainable.

comment.narrative: There are no financial mechanisms in place to cover the costs for the LCM of Hg containing lamps (CFLs and tubes).
Business plan for the collection, transport, temporary storage and treatment of different types of Hg wastes finalized.
The business plan is being developed by the business model expert and is expected to be presented on October for validation on November 2015.
Assessment of potential Cost-Recovery Mechanisms including recommendations for tax tariffs, tax modalities and channeling of funds, completed (to inform drafting of EPR degree).
The cost recovery mechanisms are being developed as part of the business plan.
30 personnel of private sector entities trained in LCM of Hg containing wastes and waste products.
Not applicable until the treatment facility is in place

Bidding process for private sector operators completed.
Business operations launched (collection, transportation, interim storage and treatment).
Not applicable yet.

description.narrative: Strengthening technical capacity and infrastructure for the treatment and storage (medium – and long- term) of Mercury containing wastes.
Technology to treat collected Hg containing product waste operational.

comment.narrative: In the whole of Uruguay there are no options for the treatment of Mercury containing products.
Technical specifications for the treatment facility, (in-line with Basel Convention guidelines and in compliance with national regulations), developed.
Draft Technical specifications for the international bidding process of the treatment facility are being developed by the international expert in close coordination with the project team.
Operational procedures for the treatment technology developed and implemented.
Not applicable yet.
2 - 3 private sector operators and 30 PCTP staff trained in the safe operation of the treatment facility/technology
Not applicable yet
Operation of decontamination facility officially launched.
Not applicable yet.

description.narrative: Intermediate Hg storage options established and long-term storage options identified.

comment.narrative: In the whole of Uruguay there are no safe options for the sound interim storage of Mercury containing products/wastes or the long-term storage of elemental Mercury.
Assessment for short-term, interim and long-term storage and disposal options completed
Short-term, interim and long-term storage facilities are being identified and designed as part of the national plan on the LCM of products containing mercury and mercury wasteswastes
Operational procedures developed and implemented for the management of storage facilities/spaces.
Not applicable yet.
Safe interim storage spaces for Mercury containing products available/established at model facilities and PCTP and staff trained in the safe management of storage spaces.
Not applicable yet
Safe long-term storage of recovered elemental Mercury established (in-line with BC guidelines and in compliance with national regulations) .
Not applicable yet

description.narrative: Strengthening national and regional awareness on the Sound Life-Cycle Management of Mercury containing products as well as associated health hazards resulting from mismanagement
National capacity to monitor Mercury levels in populations strengthened.

comment.narrative: As part of a CIAT/USAID pilot project (2006) bio-monitoring of Mercury levels in healthcare staff was undertaken by CIAT’s poison control center at a model facility.
Technical specifications for PCTP/CIAT bio-monitoring laboratory equipment prepared.

The technical specifications for PCTP/CIAT bio-monitoring laboratory equipment were prepared in coordination with the PCTP technical experts. The international bidding for procurement of the laboratory equipment was launched in march 2015.
PCTP is currently capable of monitoring Hg in environmental media, and have at their disposal a Jerome analyzer for air monitoring.
International procurement process successfully completed.

A laboratory equipment MILESTONE DMA-80 and supplies and reagents for the processing of 1000 samples were successfully procured through an international bidding process.
The equipment was delivered to PCTP on June 24, 2015.
Laboratory equipment with the same characteristics will be acquired for the health sector, and will be located in the Ministry of Public Health Laboratory , considering its performance to also process biological samples.
As a result of the good purchase management regarding the equipment for the environmental area, there is some additional budget available. This opens the possibility of buying more laboratory equipment for the area of health.
The country has no continuous/frequent monitoring system in place for Hg levels.
Protocol for sampling and analysis of Hg in water, soils, air and biological samples developed and CIAT/PCTP personnel/staff trained in sampling and conducting analysis.
The protocol for sampling and analysis of Hg in water and soils, are being developed in coordination with PCTP experts.
The country has no capacity for analyzing Hg levels in biological samples.
??Population-at-risk study completed (samples analyzed and results interpreted by CIAT/PCTP) and results published.

Through a participatory process with project partner institutions (MSP, ASSE, CIAT) and other institutions related to health, it was decided that two population studies will be conducted to determine mercury levels in: (i) pregnant women - newborns; (ii) working population being exposed to Mercury releases.
The first study will be conducted by CIAT and ASSE and the second one by MSP.
It is expected that projects will be submitted to the National Ethics Committee during the second half of 2015, in line with the requirements for the development of these kind of studies.

Continuous environmental and bio-monitoring programme developed for project model facilities (treatment facility, storage facilities and maintenance/storage staff) to analyze Hg levels in air, soil, water as well as in biological samples frequently and beyond project duration.
Not applicable yet.

description.narrative: Awareness on LCM of Mercury containing products increased among project stakeholders, the general public and countries at regional and global level.

comment.narrative: BCCC LAC has a website which it uses for information dissemination. BCCC LAC also leads a network of national Basel Convention Centers through which information on hazardous waste management can be disseminated.
Website and Facebook page developed and regularly updated (English and Spanish).

An agreement was reached with the Basel Convention Coordinating Centre (BCCC) to spread Project information through its website.
Another agreement was reached with DINAMA for the development of a Project Website,in coordination with BCCC.

Project related documentation (legislation, guidelines, national plans, model facility plans, operational and testing protocols, Hg monitoring studies, etc.) all published on the project website and disseminated among regional and int. partners.
Not applicable yet
Side event organized at a chemicals-related COP (Basel, Minamata) to present project results and lessons-learned.
Not applicable yet.
Video on the LCM of Mercury management produced at the end of project implementation to share lessons-learned.
Not applicable yet.

description.narrative: Monitoring, adaptive feedback, outreach and evaluation.
Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

comment.narrative: No documents in baseline situation.
4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year

A monthly report is sent to project partner institutions: MSP, ASSE, CIAT, PCTP, AOU,LATU, UTE, AUCI, PNUD and DINAMA.
On June 2015, the project implementation report (covering the period since the project launch in October 2014) was presented at a Steering Committee Meeting.
1 annual APR/PIR submitted to UNDP each year.
This is the first PIR of the Project. The 2014 annual report was submitted to the UNDP Country Office on December 2014.
1 Mid-term project review.
Not applicable yet
1 Final evaluation.
Not applicable yet
MTE and FE must include a lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results.
Not applicable yet

title.narrative: URU/13/002 Apoyo a la ejecución del PDGS

title.narrative: URU/13/001 Proyecto marco de apoyo a la estrategia de CS

description.narrative: Proyecto marco de apoyo a la estrategia de CSS

El presente proyecto tiene por propósito apoyar a la Agencia Uruguaya de cooperación Internacional en la Estrategia de Cooperación Sur Sur (CSS) y cooperación triangular, y a la implementación de iniciativas específicas en el marco de dicha estrategia.
capital of a political entity

title.narrative: URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema

description.narrative: URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema Nacional de Áreas Protegidas incluyendo el enfoque de paisaje en la gestión”.

title.narrative: URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema
URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema

description.narrative: URU/13/G35 Fortalecimiento de la efectividad del Sistema Nacional de Áreas Protegidas incluyendo el enfoque de paisaje en la gestión”.

The Uruguayan Protected Areas System incorporates a landscape approach to management, strengthening the effectiveness of PAs as nuclei for the conservation of globally important species and ecosystems
Area and condition (as measured by the Pasture Conservation Index ICP) of natural pasture habitat for important bird species in PAs and surrounding areas:

comment.narrative:
Area (ha) under natural pasture by site:
Farrapos + Mafalda = 13,384 ha
Queguay = 111,225 ha
Lunarejo + Laureles = 230,369 ha
Rocha + Garzón = 104,695 ha
Total = 459,673 ha
No net loss in area or condition of natural pastures in the target areas.

The base line for this indicator was estimated using low resolution satellite images. However, the project partially supported the acquisition of high-resolution satellite images (on 2015). This allowed the enforcement of a new and more detailed ecosystem surface measurement methodology in broad territories, which will be the data source for various indicators to be included in the Monitoring and Evaluation System that is being designed. It was considered as highly convenient to use the same data source for the calculation of various indicators. Therefore a new base line was generated for this indicator. See Annex: Methodological Reference for logic framework indicators. (Anexo Referencia metodológica para indicadores del marco logico).
To date, the indicator was applied in Tacuarembó department (target zone Northern Canyons), in Río Negro department (target zone Western Littoral) and in the entire target zone Coastal lagoons. For the rest of North Canyon (Rivera) the image processing is yet to be performed, and for the area Montes del Queguay of Western Littoral images are to be acquired. Complete results will be available towards the end of 2015. The chart below presents the results obtained on June 2015. The indicator will be calculated again on 2018.
New base line:
Priority Ecosystem
Surface in hectares per target area (*) Discrimination of total area per type of forest is still in process.
North canyons (Only Tacuarembó)
Natural grassland 125.669
Western littoral (Only Río Negro)
Natural grassland 11.657
Coastal lagoons (entire target zone)
Natural grassland 93.240

The base line for this indicator was estimated using low resolution satellite images. However, the project partially supported the acquisition of high-resolution satellite images (on 2015). This allowed the enforcement of a new and more detailed ecosystem surface measurement methodology in broad territories, which will be the data source for various indicators to be included in the Monitoring and Evaluation System that is being designed. It was considered as highly convenient to use the same data source for the calculation of various indicators. Therefore a new base line was generated for this indicator. See Annex: Methodological Reference for logic framework indicators. (Anexo Referencia metodológica para indicadores del marco logico).
To date, the indicator was applied in Tacuarembó department (target zone Northern Canyons), in Río Negro department (target zone Western Littoral) and in the entire target zone Coastal lagoons. For the rest of North Canyon (Rivera) the image processing is yet to be performed, and for the area Montes del Queguay of Western Littoral images are to be acquired. Complete results will be available towards the end of 2015. The chart below presents the results obtained on June 2015. The indicator will be calculated again on 2018.

description.narrative: Reductions in the incidence of IAS in PAs

comment.narrative:
Incidence of Gleditsia triachanthos in Farrapos:
1-40% / 49 ha
40-61% / 40 ha
61-100% / 110 ha

Incidence of Gleditsia triachanthos in Farrapos:
1-40% / 49 ha
40-61% / 80 ha
61-100% / 70 ha

In 2014 approximately 600 ha of Esteros de Farrapos protected area were estimated to have incidence of invasive species. Aiming to update the baseline, new high-resolution satellite images were acquired and a new methodology to estimate the indicator was proposed. (See Anexo Referencia metodológica para indicadores del marco lógico ). Base line values per coverage level are being adjusted during 2015. Afterwards, the program for controlling invasive species will begin.

description.narrative: System level Protected Area frameworks consolidated to adopt the landscape approach

% of DINAMA staff with capacities for interaction with landscape level actors and processes: target values to be quantified on the basis of staff assessment at project start]

Institutionalized agreement in reference to criteria, values and guidelines regarding biodiversity in planning process and environmental regulation did not exist until 2014. During 2015 a joint working agenda SNAP-Biodiversity Division-DINOT was agreed aimed to promote biodiversity and conservation mainstreaming in spatial planning tools. Planned activities under this agreement include (among others): qualification training for DINOT and DINAMA staff and departmental technical staff, and the update of the Guidelines for Spatial Planning published by DINOT in 2013.
The indicator will be measured in 2016 and 2018 after one year of joint agenda approval and implementation. See "Anexo Referencia metodológica para medición de indicadores del marco lógico".

description.narrative: Reduction in financial gap for SNAP:

comment.narrative: Financial gap for SNAP as a whole: 30% ($999,000)
20% reduction in financial gap for SNAP as a whole, to 24% ($800,000)

During 2015, SNAP´s budget was arranged for its inclusion in the five-year MVOTMA 2016-2020 budget. Human resources and necessary founds for a basic management of the System were estimated, taking into consideration the foreknown evolution of the SNAP physical network. As well, a proposal of tax incentives for privates to donate to the Protected Areas Fund was put forward for consideration of the parliament.. The five-year budget will be approved by the parliament on the last trimester of this year. If the proposal is approved, an additional source of funds may be available to finance the System.
Results from these actions could be appreciated from 2016 on. The indicator will be measured in 2016 and 2018

description.narrative: Area of land with tax exemptions due to inclusion in SNAP

comment.narrative: 0ha
Lunarejo: 3,321ha, Laguna de Rocha: 707ha

A proposal to exclude the payment of the rural real estate tax ( land tax collected by local government) to rural properties located in areas of minimum, low or medium intervention regarding the Management Plan of a protected area, was put forward for inclusion in the National Budget Law
The indicator will be measured annually from 2016.

description.narrative: Area of land in Laureles Cañas and Queguay with tax exemptions due to native forest cover

comment.narrative: None of the 6,790ha native forest in Laureles and Queguay is declared for tax exemption
4,074ha (60%) of the native forest in Laureles and Queguay is declared for tax exemption

Required modifications for the agreement between MGAP and DINAMA associated to the native forest, are being discussed, in order to extend its enforcement in Laureles – Cañas, that is not a protected area registered in SNAP and therefore it is kept outside the agreement.
The indicator will be measured annually from 2016.

description.narrative: Amount of resources from Protected Area Fund received by SNAP

comment.narrative: Annual Operating Plan 2015 does not prioritize action lines regarding this objective. The indicator will be measured annually from 2016.

description.narrative: Protected area management integrated with adjacent landscapes
Increase in METT scores in 7 PAs covering 214,336ha

comment.narrative:
Farrapos = 50
Lunarejo =45
Laureles -Cañas = 11
Rocha = 45
Garzón = 11
Queguay = 24
Mafalda = 60

Farrapos = 83
Lunarejo = 76
Laureles-Cañas = 46
Rocha = 80
Garzón = 46
Queguay = 49
Mafalda = 75
The process of planning for the application of METT started in July 2015. Results will be available on November 2015.

description.narrative: Effectiveness of mechanisms for stakeholder participation in planning and management

comment.narrative: CAEs exist in all three target PAs declared to date, with broad participation but no mechanisms for feedback or evaluation of effectiveness and satisfaction

All 7 PAs to be included in the project have CAEs with functioning mechanisms for feedback and evaluation of effectiveness and satisfaction, and CAEs receive consistent positive rating from stakeholder participants

The indicator will be measured towards the ending of 2015. This year’s goal: all AP entered to SNAP prior to 2014 have formalized CAE. (See Annex: Referencia metodológica para medición de indicadores del marco lógico). The introduction of mechanisms for feedback and evaluation of the effectiveness and performance of the CAEs is planned for the year 2016.

description.narrative: Number of Departmental-level zoning plans that make specific reference to PAs and their areas of influence

comment.narrative:
Coastal Lagoons:
- Coastal Lagoons Local Plan (covering Rocha and Garzón lagoons)
Western Littoral:
- Guichón Micro-Region Local Plan for Zoning and Sustainable Development (covering Montes de Queguay)

Coastal Lagoons:
- Coastal Lagoons Local Plan (covering Rocha and Garzón)
Western Littoral:
- Guichón Micro-Region Local Plan
- Departmental zoning plan covering Farrapos
Northern Canyons:
- Departmental Zoning Plans for Rivera and Tacuarembó (covering Lunarejo and Laureles Cañas)

In 2014 the methodological process to measure this indicator was developed and the baseline created: from 8 spatial plans approved and linked to the target zones, 6 have some sort of reference to SNAP. Indicator’s results for 2014 are: Western littoral: 2,5 / North Canyons: 0 / Coastal lagoon: 3,9. Total target areas: 2,75. (max. 6). (See Annex: Referencia metodológica para medición de indicadores del marco lógico).
In this period SNAP participated in the Strategic Environmental Evaluation (carried out by DINAMA) of Department Spatial Planning Guidelines (Directrices Departamentales de Ordenamiento Territorial) of Tacuarembó and Rio Negro. As result, both instruments incorporate specific contributions for including the landscape approach in spatial planning for conservation in target zones territories. The indicator will be measured again in 2016

description.narrative: Levels of staff assignment in Departmental governments for supporting integration of PA management with land use planning

comment.narrative: 3 of the 6 Departmental Governments covering the target areas have staff with specific responsibilities for planning and management of rural areas, including those in or adjoining PAs

All 6 of the Departmental Governments covering the target areas (Río Negro, Paysandú, Maldonado, Rocha, Rivera and Tacuarembó) have staff with specific responsibilities for planning and management of rural areas, including those in or adjoining PAs

Due to the change in departmental authorities on 2015, a new baseline will be created according to new situation, on the second half of the year. However the joint working agenda agreed with DINOT includes qualification training and technology transfer to departmental governments in order to support and promote the inclusion of more trained personnel in rural spatial planning processes.

description.narrative: Area of forestry properties where design and management of set-asides incorporate landscape-wide BD considerations (such as the size and spatial configuration of pasture areas in relation to vertical barriers such as forestry plantations, and the spatial configuration, condition and flowering/ seeding status of pasture grasses, which determine the value of the set-asides for pasture birds)

comment.narrative: 188,688ha of forestry plantation properties in target landscapes, of which an estimated 15% is set-asides (28,303ha), all of which are planned and managed on individual basis
50% of set-asides (14,152ha) in forestry plantations in target landscapes are planned and managed in accordance with landscape-wide considerations

SNAP participated with forestry producers and the academic sector in the cycle of workshops organized by the University of the Republic aimed to analyze the new exigencies of the standard FSC and identify new indicators for the national standard. In addition SNAP and the Society of Forest Producers started the negotiations for the definition of a national protocol to identify areas of high value of conservation in forest plantations and the agreement on criteria for planning and management in such zones of conservation. Indicator will be measured once the criteria for planning and management are agreed.

description.narrative: Areas with public use and tourism plans in accordance with the national guidelines on tourism in protected areas (currently being prepared)

comment.narrative: None, as the guidelines are still under preparation
To be determined

On August 2014 the Guidelines for Public Use in Protected Areas was approved by MINTUR and MVOTMA and the UNIT Rule for Sustainable Tourism in Protected Area was published.
On June 2015, jointly with METT evaluation, the planning process for the application of the tool Monitoring effectiveness of the public use foreknown on the guidelines has begun, in order to establish the indicator’s baseline.
